Award.AwardTitle: Fiber Laser Frequency Combs for the Advanced Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides funding to implement and evaluate ultrafast optics and fiber laser frequency comb advanced laboratories at Bethel University and the College of Optical Sciences at the University of Arizona. Fiber laser frequency combs based on a proven, cost-efficient carbon nanotube design will be built and utilized at the University of Arizona in its graduate-level optics lab and at Bethel University in its upper-level physics courses. Bethel is a primarily undergraduate institution (18 graduates per year averaged over the last five years) with a strong history of open-ended advanced lab projects. The growing number of applications of a fiber laser frequency comb (e.g. precision length measurement and molecular spectroscopy) will serve to enhance the creativity and novelty of Bethel University's advanced lab context. The ultrafast laser and fiber laser frequency comb labs will educate and train graduate and undergraduate students in laser science, linear and non-linear optics, engineering and ultrafast measurement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has produced a set of ultrafast (sub-ps pulse durations) optics labs that is perhaps somewhat uncommon in the undergraduate lab. The concepts and required skills are used in state-of-the-art physics, engineering and industrial settings. In contrast to common ultrafast systems such as mode-locked titanium-sapphire lasers, the lasers built in this project are relatively inexpensive due in large part to the wide availability of telecommunications components and equipment. Dramatically lower cost could make ultrafast optics accessible for many undergraduate physics and engineering programs.

We have built several mode-locked erbium fiber lasers in the context of undergraduate advanced lab courses at Bethel. One of these lasers has resulted in a frequency comb: students measured the repetition rate and carrier-envelope offset frequency of the pulses. Two of these lasers were built using face-coupling fiber connectors, bringing the total cost as low as 3400 USD. We have also built a low-cost auto-correlator for pulse characterization and a parallel-grating dispersion compensation apparatus. Each of these devices can function as stand-alone exercises for the mode-locked laser in an advanced lab. We have disseminated computer code for modeling ultrashort pulses on our group website. 

The procedures for these labs, equipment lists, results, etc.\ have been disseminated nationwide via seven student conference presentations (16 student co-authors), five Advanced Laboratory Physics Association (ALPhA) Immersions and hands-on conference workshops. Participants received a set of materials, including an equipment list with prices, such that they can reproduce the apparatus and exercises at their home institution. The co-PI, Dr. Jason Jones, led a separate, simultaneous Immersion on a more advanced fiber laser comb apparatus.

We have submitted an article to the American Journal of Physics. The PI has been invited to give seven talks on the fiber laser comb advanced lab project. Students from Bethel have made visits to the co-PI's lab at the University of Arizona College of Optical Sciences to master the techniques and gain experience in a top-notch research lab. The fiber laser advanced lab was featured in talks by the PI and a Bethel student given at the first annual 2016 University of Arizona College of Optical Sciences Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop, partially funded under a separate grant by the NSF.

A physics education research (PER) group at the University of Colorado, Boulder, led by Dr. Heather Lewandowski, has studied of the effects of this fiber laser advanced lab in two of the PI's courses (Optics and Lasers). The group spent time at Bethel interviewing students and collecting data through weekly and periodic surveys on these projects in 2015 and 2016, focusing on aspects of student ownership of the projects. These results have been reported at PER conferences and in publications and are some of the first PER studies of an advanced undergraduate project-based lab course.

Twelve undergraduates in five advanced lab project groups, including two women, in the PI's Lasers and Optics courses since 2014 helped develop different aspects of the fiber comb and connector-based laser. Eleven students (two women) participated in summer research and Senior Projects, some going on to Ph.D. programs in optics, physics and electrical engineering. 

Seven students (one woman) with 16 student co-authors presented results from the project at national conferences. These included DAMOP meetings, the Symposium on Undergraduate Research at the APS Division of Laser Science annual meeting, and AAPT and ALPhA meetings.

NSF funding has provided the resources to advance UA's education experiences for graduate students at the UA and to collaborate and assist Bethel University in developing such projects for their undergraduate students. We expect the advances made in our standard teaching lab (511L) will continue to be used for many years to come, and the co-PI plans to implement more aspects of the fs frequency comb in this course as well as in future independent student projects.

With NSF support, we have developed a low-cost optical frequency comb system and an even lower-cost ultrafast fiber laser. Both of these systems are suitable for use in the undergraduate lab as well-defined exercises, open-ended projects or a basis for research. The high performance capable with the frequency comb could be used in ultrafast, optical, atomic and molecular research groups.

The broader impact of this work includes dozens of students at Bethel University in the PI's Optics and Lasers courses, and summer and Senior Research students. It also includes graduate and post-doctoral researchers at Boulder and Arizona, and, through the Immersions and workshops, dozens of faculty from institutions around the nation. The collaboration led to several Bethel students spending extensive time in the labs at Arizona. There, they not only learned fiber laser techniques but experienced a top-notch research group and perhaps were inspired to graduate school.
